# Steps to geerate token for kubernetes dashboard

## create service account

Execute the following scripts:

```bash
kubectl apply -f dashboard-adminuser.yaml
```

The expected output is "serviceaccount/admin-user created"

## create cluster role binding

Execute the following scripts:

```bash
kubectl apply -f admin-clusterrole.yaml
```

The expected output is "clusterrolebinding.rbac.authorization.k8s.io/admin-user created"

## generate token

Execute the following scripts:

```bash
sh get-token.sh
```

and it should print something like this

eyJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsImtpZCI6IiJ9..Z2JrQlitASVwWbc-s6deLRFVk5DWD3P_vjUFXsqVSY10pbjFLG4njoZwh8p3tLxnX_VBsr7_6bwxhWSYChp9hwxznemD5x5HLtjb16kI9Z7yFWLtohzkTwuFbqmQaMoget_nYcQBUC5fDmBHRfFvNKePh_vSSb2h_aYXa8GV5AcfPQpY7r461itme1EXHQJqv-SN-zUnguDguCTjD80pFZ_CmnSE1z9QdMHPB8hoB4V68gtswR1VLa6mSYdgPwCHauuOobojALSaMc3RH7MmFUumAgguhqAkX3Omqd3rJbYOMRuMjhANqd08piDC3aIabINX6gP5-Tuuw2svnV6NYQ

Now copy the token and paste it into Enter token field on the login screen

## Clean

We can truncate the created account by executing

```bash
sh clean-up.sh
```
